thread.title: Byfuglien's dramatic goal gives Winnipeg Jets home-opener win over Calgary Flame
thread.title_full: Byfuglien's dramatic goal gives Winnipeg Jets home-opener win over Calgary Flame

author: torontosun.com
title: Byfuglien's dramatic goal gives Winnipeg Jets home-opener win over Calgary Flame
text:
The Winnipeg Jets never had a doubt the decisive goal was going to count, even after it went to review.
Jets defenceman Dustin Byfuglien forced Johnny Gaudreau into a turnover in the neutral zone, put the puck between his skates just inside the offensive blue line before going around defenceman Dennis Wideman and fooling Karri Ramo (who lost his footing) with a shot from a bad angle to propel his team to a 3-1 victory over the Calgary Flames.
After the apparent go-ahead goal, Flames head coach Bob Hartley used his coach's challenge to see if the marker would be overturned because of a potential offside.
However, the situation confirmed that Byfuglien had control of the puck when he entered the zone and the goal stood.
“I knew I was onside, because I had the puck,” said Byfuglien, who has two goals and four points in five games this season. “I just went down the wall and tried something I don't do very often and it happened to work.”
The Jets, who improved to 4-1 and equal the best start in franchise history, continue a six-game homestand on Sunday afternoon against the St. Louis Blues.
Byfuglien's goal was a thing of beauty and the Jets simply felt the Flames were using the coach's challenge to buy some extra time.
“We saw it pretty clear, the rule is pretty clear. We weren't worried about it,” said Jets head coach Paul Maurice. “At that point, a review is going to take a lot longer than a timeout. That was as much, in my mind, to extend (the delay) as long as they can. Which was good for us too. We got our defensive guys rested.”
Maurice tweaked his defence pairings during the second period, reuniting Byfuglien with Toby Enstrom and moving Tyler Myers with Adam Pardy and the move paid dividends.
“It's so unusual for a man that big to do some of the things that he can do, at high rates of speed,” said Maurice. “The second half of that game, he was really good all over the ice. In his own end and making plays. He helped us get our offensive game going.”
Since relocating from Atlanta, the Jets are now 2-3 in home openers and are 7-7-2 all-time as a franchise.
The Flames scored first as Mikael Backlund deposited the rebound after Ondrej Pavelec stopped Sam Bennett on a wraparound attempt at 3:38 of the first period.
But the Jets took advantage of a fortuitous bounce to even the score as Blake Wheeler caromed a pass in front off the right skate of Little.
“Once we tied that game in the second period, we found a new gear and controlled the play a lot more,” said Little, who has three goals in his past two games. “And that was a big goal by (Byfuglien) in the third. He's a guy that's fun to watch when he's playing his game. He's just so strong on the puck and he shows he's got a nice pair of hands and great shot too. When he wants to take that puck to the net, there's not many guys in this league that can stop him.”
After producing 11 shots on goal in the first period, the Flames were held to only four shots during the second and needed nearly 11 minutes to record their first shot of the third, finishing with 20 overall.
But Pavelec managed to stay sharp despite the lack of work, making the necessary saves when called upon to improve to 2-1 on the season, while lowering his goals against average to 2.01 and raising his save percentage to .936.
“You have to, you have no choice,” said Pavelec. “It's about how you focus for every shot and for every minute.”
There was a scary moment for the Jets during the third period as Wheeler appeared to suffer a wrist injury, but after a quick trip to the dressing room to get taped up, the right-winger was back on the ice and didn't miss a shift.
Although Wheeler wasn't available to comment, he supplied the insurance marker by scoring an empty-netter with 52.8 seconds left in regulation, moving him to three goals and seven points in five games this season.
“It's just work,” said Maurice. “He looks like he's going harder than everybody else on the ice. He's had some games where I don't think he was overly excited about the way it was going for him and he's ended up with a point or two.”
ken.wiebe@sunmedia.ca

WINNIPEG JETS
Byfuglien's dramatic goal gives Winnipeg Jets home-opener win over Calgary Flames
By Ken Wiebe , Winnipeg Sun First posted: Friday, October 16, 2015 10:49 PM EDT | Updated: Friday, October 16, 2015 11:53 PM EDT
Dustin Byfuglien has a flair for the dramatic.
The Winnipeg Jets defenceman forced a turnover in the neutral zone with under two minutes to play and put the puck between his legs before fooling Karri Ramo with an off-speed shot to propel his team to a 3-1 victory over the Calgary Flames.
Byfuglien's goal wasn't without a hint of controversy as Flames head coach Bob Hartley used his coach's challenge to see if the marker would be overturned because of an offside.
However, the goal stood and gave Byfuglien his second of the season.
The Jets, who improved to 4-1, continue a six-game homestand on Sunday afternoon against the St. Louis Blues.
Since relocating from Atlanta, the Jets are now 2-3 in home openers and are 7-7-2 all-time as a franchise.
Following the opening ceremony, the Jets came out and threw their weight around a bit but it was the Flames that scored first.
